awd_titl_txt: Algebraic Learning and Cognition in Learning Disabled Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal was submitted in response to EHR Core Research (ECR) program announcement NSF 15-509. The ECR program of fundamental research in STEM education provides funding in critical research areas that are essential, broad and enduring. EHR seeks proposals that will help synthesize, build and/or expand research foundations in the following focal areas: STEM learning, STEM learning environments, STEM workforce development, and broadening participation in STEM. The ECR program is distinguished by its emphasis on the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to (a) understand, (b) build theory to explain, and (c) suggest interventions (and innovations) to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning, and participation.

High school algebra is the gateway to a career in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), and can influence employability and wages in many non-STEM occupations. Students who struggle with or fail high school algebra have compromised occupational prospects, and nations that do not produce mathematically competent citizens may compromise their economic growth. Much is known about the factors that contribute to students' difficulties with arithmetic learning and interventions are being developed to address these difficulties. Little is known, however, about why some students struggle with algebra. Accordingly, the project will follow at risk students (including for example, those with dyslexia) from 7th grade through high school algebra and assess their prerequisite knowledge (e.g. fractions skills), cognitive systems (e.g., memory), attitudes and reactions to mathematics (e.g. math anxiety) and their attentiveness in math classrooms. The comprehensive evaluation of these students will allow us to identify the factors that influence difficulties in learning different aspects of algebra and risk of failing algebra more generally. The results will provide unique scientific insights into the cognitive and motivational influences on students' understanding and learning of algebra and identify areas for intervention with at-risk students. The results will also be used to develop a screening measure for the early identification of at-risk students and to identify specific areas for targeted intervention. The measure will be made freely available to interested school districts throughout the United States.  

The project is a 7th to 9th grade longitudinal assessment of the prerequisite (e.g. fractions), cognitive (e.g. working memory), and non-cognitive (e.g. math anxiety) factors that dynamically influence students' algebraic learning and cognition, with a focus on students with learning disabilities in mathematics. The study will provide the most comprehensive assessment of the development of algebra competence ever conducted and is organized by an integrative model of cognitive and non-cognitive influences on students' engagement in math classrooms and on the learning of procedural and spatial-related aspects of algebra. The focus on students at risk for failing high school algebra is informed by research on the number and arithmetic deficits of these students, providing continuity with previous work, and a strong a priori framework for assessing their most likely difficulties in learning algebra; specifically, we developed novel measures that assess different aspects of procedural algebra (e.g. memory for the structure of algebra equations) and spatial-related algebra (e.g. recognizing how common functions map to coordinate space) that will allow for the study of different types of learning deficits and a determination of how more basic cognitive abilities, such as visuospatial working memory, may underlie these deficits. Prior cognitive studies of at-risk students have largely ignored the contributions of non-cognitive factors, such as math anxiety, on their learning or how their learning difficulties change attitudes about and reactions to mathematics (e.g. increasing math anxiety). The proposed research will address this important oversight and integrate these non-cognitive factors with assessments of teacher-rated student engagement in pre-algebra and algebra classrooms (and language arts classrooms as a contrast) and how engagement in the classroom influences the learning of procedural and spatial-related algebra. The research will also provide a thorough analysis of cognitive and non-cognitive influences on algebraic learning and cognition more generally, and thus inform general educational practices. In all, the proposed research will provide a comprehensive model for the study algebraic learning and cognition generally, and will provide a comprehensive assessment of associated deficits of learning disabled students and students at risk for failing high school algebra. The research will also make available revised or newly developed cognitive measures of procedural and spatial-related algebra skills that should facilitate future cognitive science and educational studies of algebra learning.

por.por_cntn:
Strong algebra skill provide the foundation for the mathematics needed for decision making in many aspects of day-to-day life; is demanded in high-paying technology and science fields; and contributes to employability and wages in many blue-collar occupations. The importance of algebra was highlighted by the National Mathematics Advisor Panel (NMAP, 2008):

[The] concerns of national policy relating to mathematics education go far beyond those in our society who will become scientists or engineers. The national workforce of future years will surely have to handle quantitative concepts more fully and more deftly than at present. So will the citizens and policy leaders who deal with the public interest in positions of civic leadership. Sound education in mathematics across the population is a national interest. (NMAP 2008, pp. xi-xii).

Yet only 39% of US high school graduates have the algebraic competencies needed for these endeavors. Improving the algebra knowledge and skills of US students will yield individual and wider social benefits, but this goal has been difficult to achieve. One impediment is our piecemeal understanding of algebra learning and cognition that has resulted in both practical and theoretical costs. Practically, one student may have difficulty due to an undervaluation of the importance of mathematics (low utility beliefs) and another may have poorly developed prerequisite skills. In other words, there are many factors that can result in poor development of algebra knowledge and skills, but the combination of potential factors and the most important ones are not well understood.

The project provided the most thorough assessment to date of the relation between prerequisite math competencies (e.g., understanding fractions), cognitive skills (e.g., spatial abilities, working memory), mathematics attitudes (i.e., self-efficacy, and beliefs about the usefulness of mathematics) and mathematics anxiety, and in-class attentive behavior on high school students’ algebra competencies. More specifically, 1,926 6th graders were assessed on their basic understanding of whole number and fractions arithmetic and on their mathematics attitudes and anxiety, and 342 of them were assessed multiple times in 7th, 8th, and 9th grades, inclusive. These included assessments of their mathematics attitudes and anxiety, their cognitive skills, in-class attentive behavior, and their mathematics and reading achievement. The 9th grade assessments included a broad evaluation of their algebra knowledge and skills, including performance on a high-stakes, State (Missouri) required (for high school graduation) end-of-course algebra test.

Spatial abilities, in-class attentive behavior, and mathematics anxiety stood out as important contributors to mathematical development during the middle school years and into high school algebra. Spatial abilities and in-class attentive behavior were particularly important. Above and beyond these influences, 6th graders who did not have a strong understanding of mathematical equality (i.e., what the ‘=’ means) and did not have a good understanding of the magnitudes represented by fractions were at high risk of failing the high-stakes end-of-course algebra test in 9th grade. Using these results, a screening measure was developed to help identify these at-risk students at the end of 6th grade; this provides a two-year window to remediate basic skills before taking high school algebra.

The results more generally highlighted the importance of spatial abilities for mathematics learning through middle school and into high school algebra. Spatial abilities were found to be important for learning newly presented math material and for performance on algebra word problems. The latter was found controlling for broad mathematics achievement and domain-general abilities (e.g., working memory), indicating that spatial strategies might be especially important for setting up and solving word problems; word problems are common on high-stakes tests and predict readiness for college math and the workforce.

Overall, we found no sex differences in mathematics, in part because girls’ better in-class attentive behavior compensated for less developed spatial abilities, whereas boys’ better spatial abilities compensated for less engagement in mathematics classrooms. Performance on algebra word problems was one exception. Here, boys outperformed girls, and this was mediated by spatial abilities and mathematics anxiety. Stated differently, there is no sex difference in algebra knowledge and skills, except in areas in which spatial visualization or spatial problem solving can aid performance or learning.

We also found that boys have lower mathematics anxiety and better mathematics attitudes than girls, but the developmental trajectory (from 7th to 9th grade) in these areas is similar for boys and girls. For both girls and boys, slow math development from 7th to 9th grade was related to cross-grade increases in math anxiety and more negative attitudes about mathematics, both of which are associated with later avoidance of mathematics.

The results all point to the importance of incorporating spatial representations into middle school and high school mathematics instruction and suggest that mathematics anxiety can disrupt the learning of some students. The results also provide a means for identifying students at risk for difficulties with algebra and the development of associated remedial interventions.
